title: Bard is What CertainlyT's Champions Should Strive to Be
body:
Everyone already knows that CertainlyT's champions always introduce some interesting new mechanic that while fun for the player, isn't exactly interactive or fun for anyone else in the game. The thing is, champions don't _need_ to be aggravating to play against in order to introduce new mechanics to the game. Take Bard for example. Bard is an incredibly unique champion that introduces a new and interesting mechanic with each and every one of his abilities. However, unlike champions like Yasuo or Zoe, Bard is fun to play against for the enemy as well. Bard has clear counterplay in many of his abilities and he also doesn't get a safety net - if he screws up it can actually cost him or his team greatly.

Just my thoughts on the subject. I've always like Bard due to how he's unique and fun to play against at the same time, something that unfortunately CertainlyT's champions haven't achieved.

replies.body: Bard is CertainlyNotT

Agreed, he is a good example.
Like his tunnels, which let everyone in his team get through walls, which is a new mechanic. But **enemies** can use the tunnel, too, so the new mechanic doesn't just benefit him, but the enemy team (even if obviously less than his own team).

Meanwhile CertainlyT, if he adds a new mechanic, then it is absolutely onesided for the advantage of the new champion. Like Zoe, who can use your summoner spells against yourself, so not just is she using summoner spells more frequently than anyone else, she actually **weakens** the enemy use of summoners because she can turn them against them.

Exactly, the difference between Bard and CT's champions is that Bard's design knows how to share. Meanwhile, champions like Zoe, Yasuo, Kalista, even Thresh innovate in a way that not only exclusively benefits the player playing them, but strips others of agency as well, including their own teammates at times. It's an incredibly selfish design that tries to maximize the enjoyment of one single player (and thereby likely sales and play rates of those champions), to the detriment of everyone else. This is also why I dislike the whole argument that "Yasuo is one of the most popular champions in the game", or "CT makes champions so fun to play", because those arguments focus on just one side of the entire picture, whereas champions like Bard are fun to play, play with _and_ play against.

I think the core of any champion design in League is that they should aim to maximize positive gameplay on three fronts: for the player (i.e. gameplay), for the player's opponents (i.e. counterplay), and for the player's allies (i.e. teamplay). In this respect, Bard is probably the gold standard for this, because he feels great at all three. He's proof that counterplay can be _fun_, not just bearable or within some arbitrarily acceptable level of frustration, and that a kit can be fun, and quite powerful too, without that fun automatically incurring a cost to the fun of others (which is an argument many Rioters have pulled out to justify unhealthy designs).

As a side note, I also think two-sided effects are phenomenal design that deserves to be used a lot more, especially on support kits. The problem with so many enchanters right now is that most of their gameplay boils down to pressing a button and applying pure power directly onto their allies. This is fine in small doses, but when practically an entire champion's kit boils down to this (e.g. Lulu), that champion becomes boring for many to play, and not particularly interactive. By contrast, if some (and some, not all) enchanter abilities applied the same effect to allies and enemies, perhaps via a kiss/curse effect that carries both an advantage and a disadvantage (e.g. Bard's ult), or some purely beneficial effect that both allies and enemies could access, they could afford to have much more power, and much more interesting mechanics, while also providing more interactivity. Lulu in particular I think could be a beneficiary of this, as she's supposed to be this unpredictable, mischievous fairy yordle, yet has a _very_ predictable ability set, one that applies very reliable effects that do something different, and very one-sided, to allies or enemies.

With this in mind, and going back to CT's champions, I feel applying the above kind of philosophy to at least some of his champions could perhaps make them feel a bit better to deal with:

* If Kalista's ult signaled to her Oathsworn that it was ready, and that they could activate it, or if the Oathsworn themselves were given the ult entirely (e.g. by clicking an icon above themselves or Kalista, or their Oathsworn tether), it'd give much more agency to Kalista's ally. In general, her kit could use a redo where its Oathsworn effects truly add gameplay to her ally, and not just herself (e.g. her Oathsworn could add spears on each attack, she could have some effect that'd give them some of her mobility, etc.).
* Thresh is in a more okay spot than the rest, counterplay-wise, but if his lantern could be picked up by _any_ champion, including enemies, that would make for much clearer counterplay than just sitting on the lantern to block its retrieval, and could genuinely give his opponents options to punish him (it'd also give him the option to trick and bait opponents as well, so it'd work better for everyone). In exchange, this could probably allow him to have some more power, e.g. a shorter base cooldown on his hook instead of its CDR on impact.
* This philosophy probably won't apply to Yasuo, because the champion is extremely selfish by design and doesn't really extend any opportunities for gameplay to anyone else, so much as make everything all about himself. He'd likely need other changes instead.
* If Zoe's E rendered targets immune to damage and CC until the bubble popped, and for a short moment after, instead of causing them to take amplified damage, she'd lose one of the unhealthiest parts of her gameplay, as her E would no longer be a guaranteed death sentence with her Q. Similarly, if her Q were visible at all times to all, even through Fog of War, people would be able to play against her artillery-ranged Q one-shots, since they wouldn't be coming from out of nowhere. In exchange, she could gain some _big_ buffs, namely to her Q damage. This wouldn't make her entirely healthy, because her passive and W are still a thing, but that's likely something only a full rework may be able to address.

Well, spell shields are intended to prevent damage, not destroy projectiles. If you spell shielded Ezreal's Q, then it would be blocked, because the spell still hit you, and you'd take 0 damage from it and destroys the projectile as it's a single target spell. Ezreal's w however, would not be destroyed as it's an AoE ability. The same applies to Bard's Q. You won't take damage from the ability, however it will still register that it has hit you, meaning if the second part goes on to collide with another champion/minion/wall then you will indeed be stunned. It would be borderline impossible to code it any differently.

Why does a champion have to be "fun" to play against? How do you even define that? I can defend Zoe all day saying her design is completely fine since I play champions that punish her heavily, but everybody's always going to have a different experience, so where does the line between "fun" and "unfun" get put at?
